I talked to Michael Pule about logging my dialogue footage. He suggested that I write an in-point and out-point for each clip. He also suggested the numbering method that I was considering. I think it will be best if I just do both. Clint sent me Davids final version of the script today. It includes all the shots that he wanted for each scene. I am going to meet up with Clint in McCain on Thursday to record his monologue. In the final version of the script, the monologue for the phone call scenes has been removed.

I returned all the equipment to Dole Hall today, but Bambi let me check out another camera for the weekend so that I can capture the footage. This time I just got one of the Sony TRV900 cameras. I asked Bambi if she knew the best way to log tapes for dialogue. Since I have so much dialogue footage, I was not sure what would be the best way to do this. She checked some books for me, but she was not sure what would be best. I might just write the first part of the characters line. I also might number the lines on the script and use the numbers to reference the video clips.

We are done shooting! Tonight we finished up our shooting schedule. Now we just have to hope that everything we shot will work out in post-production. If not, we may have to meet sometime next week to re-shoot some scenes. Now I have about a week and a half to edit the movie before we have to submit it to the UPC contest. There are now three and a half tapes full of footage. Chris home-made camera dolly seemed to work pretty well. It makes quite a bit of noise, so we will have to put some sound into the shots separately. There was one shot that we wanted to get with the dolly that didnt quite work out. We wanted to have the camera move backwards, away from Daren, while zooming in at the same time. This would give a cool effect of the background stretching. This is used in many movies such as Lord of the Rings. They probably do it differently though. Anyway, it didnt really work out because I could not keep the camera very steady. I hope that we got all the shots we needed for the old man scene. We started shooting later than we would have liked, so we had to shoot in a hurry. We still didnt get done until 1:00 or 1:30am. We may have to go back and get a few more shots.

I e-mailed Bambi my question about the different settings on the Sony shotgun microphone yesterday. She didnt have an answer for me, but she forwarded my e-mail to Gary Pettet, the engineer for the school. Gary sent me a response today. The switch you are referring to is a low cutoff switch. If you were to look at the Directionality chart you would see a tapering off of the pickup pattern from M, M1, to V. You would use the switch according to the ambient acoustic conditions of the room. Say for example you wanted a concert hall effect or pickup of the whole room use the M (music) position which is the full range around the mic. Use the M1 position to say make it more directional to stop a boomy sound due to bounce from the floor or reduce wind noise. This is the proximity effect. Use the V or Voice position to make it more directional and obtain clearer speech for someone talking from a distance. If you are too close to some one talking and you have a boomy voice set the position to M for more cut off and broaden the pickup pattern. So the best way is to have on a good pair of headphones and listen for the best listening results. Well, I screwed up today. I forgot to return the equipment to Kedzie and re-check it out. It looks like I will be paying a fine for that. I cant believe I forgot. This is the first time I have done that since I have been using equipment from Kedzie. I guess I was just a little tired. We finished up shooting the all of the dialogue scenes tonight. We ran late again, but at least we are finished with it. The only major problem we had was that the actors spent too much time laughing. I guess thats why we went late again. We also finished off our third tape tonight. That is way more footage than I was expecting to get. It should make things interesting in post-production. All that we have left to shoot tomorrow night is a few more slaps for Lukes flashback and the old man scene.

We began shooting the main dialogue tonight. The dialogue is very important because it will make up the majority of the movie. I am told that the overall time on the dialogue should be about 12 to 15 minutes. Before starting the dialogue, we got a few shots of Daren. The most difficult of the night was him on his knees praying. David wanted shots rotating around him. In order to do this, we tried using Chris home-made steadycam. It seemed to work alright, but we had trouble getting shots around Daren because of the small room. It became difficult to get the shots without seeing one of the lights or a reflection off of the TV or something. Well see how it works in post. The biggest problem we encountered tonight was when we began shooting Thomas dialogue. After setting up the lights and the camera, we noticed that there was a terrible reflection on Thomas glasses. We tried to move the lights to every possible location, but we had no luck eliminating the reflections. He had to wear the glasses for two reasons: it fit his character, and we had already shot some scenes with him wearing glasses. Finally, we decided to just remove the lenses, hoping that no one would be able to notice that they were gone. I think that this will actually work out very well. The other main concern of the night was with lighting. I tried to eliminate as many shadows from the shot as possible without making things worse. I dont think I did a very good job. This is my first experience with lighting and I feel clueless. Shadows are my biggest concern with lighting. Im pretty sure that I can fix any color or brightness problems in post-production. Once again we went over schedule for the night. I dont think we finished until after 1:00am. Hopefully the guys will learn their lines a little better by tomorrow night so that we can get through the script a little faster and get the shots for each character.

Today was the second day of shooting, this time entirely indoors. We shot the three phone call scenes. We were supposed to begin shooting the dialogue scene, but we ran out of time even though we ended up staying 30 minutes longer than scheduled. This means that we are officially behind schedule. There was only one scene that we completed in one take. The others had to be re-shot multiple times for various reasons. In Franks phone call scene, there were focus problems when using auto focus. I would have used manual focus the entire time, but the shot required me to pan and zoom at the same time. I would have needed a third hand in order to focus manually. I actually gained a third hand when I had David switch to manual focus in the middle of the shot. This solved the focus problem. The most tricky and time-consuming scene of the night was Lukes phone call in the bathroom. First of all, lighting was not very good. There was only flourescent lighting in the bathroom and practically no room for our additional lighting. The result was a shot with poor color. However, the biggest problem came from the mirror featured in the shot. It became difficult to get only the things we wanted to appear in the mirror. There were a few takes with other people appearing in the mirror as well as a few takes with the boom mic making an appearance. After 6 takes, we were finally able to get the shot.

Today was the first day of shooting. We were supposed to begin at 2:00pm, but I didnt know that. We didnt start until about 2:30pm or so, and finished up around 8:30pm as we watched the footage from the day. We had a pizza break at 5:30pm, which was really nice. The biggest problem of the day was the rain. It was very nice weather last week, now its cold and rainy. We had to get most of our outdoor shots today because we couldnt get all the actors later this week. Everything just looked pretty wet. I forgot to white balance a couple of the first shots, but color didnt matter too much because we are going to have to change it in post-production anyway. The shot of Thomas writing on the window did not come out as well as I had hoped. The characters were very dark when in front of the window. We tried to put light on them from the back, but it did not help much. By increasing the size of the iris, I could make the characters easier to see, but the writing on the window became almost impossible to see. I found a place somewhere in between, but the characters were still difficult to see. I am hoping that I can fix it a little bit in post-production, but Im not sure that it is possible. When shooting the scene where Daren follows the girl walking out of the bathroom, I encountered a few minor problems with the tripod. The tripod holds the camera steady only when I am not touching it. For this shot, I needed to zoom out, then pan right, then left. This caused the beginning of the shot to be a little bumpy. Once I zoomed back out, the shot seemed very stable. I will try to steady the shot in post-production. On a couple takes I noticed that the camera was having a few problems focusing. I used manual focus for a few shots during the day, and I think that I am going to use manual focus as much as possible from now on. I had more problems with lighting and shadows in the twinkie scene. I hope we can figure something out for tomorrow night. I started a tape log for everything that was shot today. I am listing the start and end times for each shot, as well as a description. This log will have a complete listing of what we are shooting each day.

I was able to get the equipment from Kedzie without too much trouble. It has been a while since the last time I had to check out equipment for a weekend, so I forgot that I needed to get a weekend checkout form.

Chris and I talked to Bambi today and told her what we were going to need for the movie. She hooked us up with a Sony PD150 camera, a nice tripod, and a light kit from Dole Hall. I have the equipment checked out until Friday, April 11. I just realized that I may run into problems picking up the audio equipment from Kedzie tomorrow because of my class schedule (it also has a bit to do with me having problems getting out of bed earlier in the morning). Ill figure something out.

I talked to Bambi after class today about getting a camera and other equipment. She said that she can get me what we will need for the next week of shooting. She wanted me to come back tomorrow at 3:00pm because she had to get to another class and she said that she would have more time tomorrow. Bambi also introduced me to Per Malm, who has been working on a feature-length movie as well as several other video projects. He is in one of my classes and I knew he was working on a movie, but I had never talked to him about it. Per was able to give me a few more suggestions for shooting. He suggested that we use two lights for the dorm room scene. The lights will need to be pointed towards the corners of the room, and we will use reflectors to bounce the light back at the actors. One will be used sort of like a key light and the other as a fill light. He said that we will probably want more lights for the night scene with the old man. As for sound, Per said that the shotgun/boom microphone would be good to use. He also said that the lavaliere microphones worked well for his movie, even when they were placed under clothing. During the test run, we found that the only microphone that will really work well for us is the shotgun microphone. The other microphones we tried were lavaliere, cardioid, and omni-directional. These microphones either picked up too much unwanted noise or picked up very little sound at all. Of all the equipment that I checked out from Kedzie, I think we will only want to use the shotgun microphone, a mixing board, and two XLR cables. I am hoping that this equipment is not used much by other students so that I wont have to worry about reserving equipment. The shotgun microphone is a Sony condenser microphone, model C-76. There are three settings for turning it on: M, M1, and V1. I have no idea how these differ from each other. I tried to find the manual for it on Sonys web site, but I could not find one. Here is the current list of equipment that we will need: camera tripod shotgun microphone XLR cables (2) mixing board camera dolly home-made steady cam light kit (from Dole)

I went to check out equipment in Kedzie today. I found out that almost all the cameras had been moved over to Dole Hall. I will try to talk to Bambi tomorrow to see if I can get a camera from there. Most of the other equipment that I needed was at Kedzie. I was told that if I want to check it out for about a week (which I need to do), then I need a note from my professor. I will be picking up the sound equipment from Kedzie for our test run tomorrow night. Here is a list of the equipment I would like to get for the test run tomorrow night: camera (Sony TRV900 or PD150) tripod (a good one that can move easily) mixing board (small; at least 4 microphone inputs) shotgun microphone (or boom microphone) light reflectors microphone stands omnidirectional microphones (2-4) cardioid microphones (2-4) MiniDisc player/recorder lavaliere microphones (2-4) I have an Archos Jukebox Recorder that has a 20GB hard drive and can record in mp3 format. I would prefer to use the Archos rather than the MiniDisc player because it would transfer digitally. The minidisc player can only do analog. I talked to Chris about helping with the production of the movie. He was very interested in helping out. He even said that he has a camera dolly that we could use. I sent him a copy of the script. Chris made a few suggestions for changing the script. He typed it all up and sent it to me. We will probably discuss the changes during the test run tomorrow night.

I finished reading urlLink Rebel Without a Crew yesterday. The second half of the book went really fast because I didn't want to put it down. Most of the things urlLink Robert Rodriguez wrote in that book seemed made up because it just sounded too good to be true. Even he said repeatedly in the book that he didn't think his new found fame would last. He said it would all probably wear off within a few days. Anyone at all interested in making movies should definitely check out this book. Now I need to find a new book to read. I've been having trouble sleeping lately. I don't know why. I have been going to bed pretty late, but it still shouldn't take me over an hour to fall asleep. I hope this doesn't keep happening. I spent most of today driving around, running errands. My mom had a job interview at Bed, Bath, and Beyond. She wants to get another job to make a little extra money for Christmas. While she was at her interview, My brother Zach and I went a few places. We checked out a new store here in Wichita called Ultimate Electronics. The place seems really fancy. All of the sales guys are wearing suits. You can tell they are working on commission. But everyone was really friendly, and they even offered us a bottle of water or coffee. I hope that urlLink Ang Lee will be directing the sequels. I hope they use the same editor too.

I made it back to Wichita last night after spending a week on the road. K-State had two days off from school, so Kyle and I went to see urlLink Darian and Kerri in Detroit over the weekend. Kyle picked me up in Wichita last Thursday, and we left Manhattan for Detroit on Friday. We spent Friday night at Yugo's place in Columbus, Indiana (just outside Indianapolis) and then he went with us to Detroit on Saturday. We all had a pretty good time in Detroit even though we were only there for about 31 hours. On Saturday we went to the art museum and then went to the MGM casino in downtown Detroit. I think Yugo was the only one that had been to a casino before, and he was the only one that made any money while we were there. It was pretty cool though. After losing my $4 at the casino, we went out to eat and topped the night off by going to see urlLink Kill Bill . That movie is AWESOME! We thought that the theater was showing it digitally, but they told us that digital movies are not available that the theater yet. We spent Sunday looking around the Detroit area a bit more. Darian took us to his office in Northville so that we could see where he worked. Then we looked around Northville a little bit and went to the mall. We also went to see the urlLink Vans Skate Park which was really cool. They have indoor and outdoor skate courses, video games, an XBox lounge, and a Vans Store. urlLink MxPx played a short acoustic set there the previous weekend. We left Detroit Sunday night and went back to Yugo's place to stay the night. Kyle and I left for Manhattan Monday morning. We stopped in St. Louis to check out the arch for a little while. I took some pretty cool pictures there. We were also going to stop in Kansas City and stay the night with Justin, but Kyle said that he needed to get back to Manhattan to get some stuff done. We did stop in Kansas City to eat dinner and hang out with Justin for a bit. The three of us walked around the Plaza for a little while. We arrived back in Manhattan Monday night a little before midnight. I had to wait until Thursday to get a ride back to Wichita with Lindsey, so I was able to hang out with Jermaine for a couple days. I think I spent about 40 hours in cars over the past week. In a way, it's kinda nice to just stay in one place for a while. And now I need to get back to my job search. I'll get my pictures from the trip up soon. I might also put some maps of the trip on my site.

Well, it looks like urlLink Hell Froze Over . Apple has released iTunes for Windows. I've been using it a bit since last night and it's actually pretty good. There are several things in iTunes that Winamp does not have. I do miss a few features from Winamp, but I might just stick iTunes for a while. This is what Nullsoft gets for not ever releasing updates to Winamp3, which is buggier than a Florida swamp! I know that the only reason that Apple released iTunes for PC is so that they can sell more mp3s, but how cool would it be if they released other Apple software for PC (Final Cut Pro)? Just a suggestion.

Happy Thanksgiving! My family and I will be leaving for Columbus, Kansas in about 6 hours (maybe). I think I forgot to mention that I did not take the job offer at Circuit City, so now I can go with my family. I guess the trip just seemed a little too important to me right now. At some point I am going to have to start letting stuff like this go. Things aren't the same anymore. Life is going to be a lot different now that I am out of school and living in the real world. But for now, Thanksgiving remains relatively the same for me. I did find out that several of my cousins will not be attending the Thanksgiving dinner in Columbus this year, and some of my other cousins are going to have to leave earlier than normal. I guess that's just part of things changing. I am still excited about Thanksgiving. I just returned from Manhattan Tuesday. I was planning on going up there Friday or Saturday for the football game with either my mom or dad. Things fell through, and we couldn't get tickets. But at the last minute, my dad and I decided to drive up there on Sunday. While I was in Manhattan, I went to eat at El Cazador's twice (Travis would have loved that). I went once with my dad, my sister, and Jermaine, and I went once with Kevin, Karl, Dustin, and Jermaine. I'm not really sure how that happened. I guess everyone was just in the mood for Mexican food this week. Jermaine told me this week that my blog sucks (although she didn't use the word "sucks"). She just thinks that I just post random, stupid stuff, and I don't really talk about anything. She's probably right. Yesterday was urlLink Darian's 24th birthday. Man, that sounds so old.

Well, I have some good news and bad news. I just had an interview at Circuit City tonight, and they offered me a seasonal job. But the only way I can take the job is if I can work the day after Thanksgiving from 5:30am to 12:00pm. Normally this would not be a problem, but my family and I have already made plans to go to my grandparents' house in Columbus, Kansas. We only get to see them and the rest of my family once or twice a year, so we always like to stay a day or two after Thanksgiving. If I have to be back in Wichita to work, that means that we will only be able to spend the afternoon in Columbus, then we would have to leave for Wichita. It just sucks that I finally have a job offer and I don't know if I can take it. I am feeling much better now as I am starting to get over this cold. I've just been sneezing a lot for the last couple days.

Well, I guess I have joined everyone else that has been getting sick lately. My throat has been hurting for the past two days. I just kinda feel like crap, and I don't have very much energy. I just hope that it doesn't last too long. I am hoping to visit Manhattan next weekend, and I might have more job interviews this week. I've just been eating a ton of cough drops! I didn't do anything too exciting this weekend. I watched Kansas State beat Nebraska, and I watched the Chiefs lose to Cincinnati. It was really cool to watch K-State win in Nebraska. This was the first time they have done that since 1968, and I was getting sick of Nebraska fans saying that K-State would never win in Nebraska. K-State is now ranked 18 and 19 in the polls, which is like seven spots higher than last week. It's too bad the Chiefs lost though. That ends the unbeaten streak this season. It just didn't seem like the Chiefs were playing very well until there was only like six minutes left in the game. By then it was too late. Oh well.

Today was a pretty big day for me. I had what I consider my first interview for a "real" job. I had an interview for a Television Producer job at the urlLink WB Kansas TV station. This position will basically be responsible for producing local advertising spots. They guy that interviewed me was really cool, and I thought the interview went very well. I received my urlLink 28 Days Later DVD in the mail today. I was somewhat disappointed that it is only one disc. It has some cool special features, but I just wish it included more. The movie was shot entirely on MiniDV camcorders ( urlLink Canon XL1S ). Although these were pretty expensive camcorders, they are still ones available to the everyday consumer. I was hoping that the special features would include more about using the MiniDV format and how they made it look more like film rather than a crappy home movie. Despite the lack of special features, I highly recommend this DVD simply because this is a beautiful movie. There are also some amazing shots of empty streets in downtown London. Speaking of good movies, I went to see urlLink Mystic River with my family last night. Like urlLink Yugo said, it is a really good movie. As good an actor as urlLink Clint Eastwood is, I think he is probably an even better director. Everyone should go see this movie. I'm sure that you will be hearing more about it at the next urlLink Academy Awards .

I'm trying to learn how to use urlLink Final Draft tonight so that I can attempt to write some screenplays. I have discovered that screenplays have a very specific style of formatting. I'm told that if a screenplay is formatted correctly, each page should be equal to about one minute when made into a movie. It looks like using Final Draft to write screenplays will be much easier than using WordPerfect or Word.

My urlLink Reservoir Dogs DVD arrived today. I got the urlLink 10th Anniversary Special Edition DVD with the Mr. Pink cover. It's pretty sweet. Reservoir Dogs was Quentin Tarantino's first major movie. I love how Tarantino takes what would normally be a pretty simple story of a robbery gone wrong and makes it into a great movie by using his unusual storytelling techniques. It was released in 1992, the same year that Robert Rodriguez's El Mariachi was released. I am expecting to receive my urlLink 28 Days Later DVD in the mail on Monday. That is another great movie that I highly recommend.

I thought I should take a moment to share the method that Brice, Brent, and I used to come up with some random shirt ideas. For those of you who would like to join in the fun but can't think of any good ideas, this is for you. You need two people in order for this to work. The first person thinks of some random picture without telling the other person what it is. The second person thinks of some random phrase without telling the other person what it is. Once a random picture and a random phrase is chosen, you sorta just put them together. Now you have a t-shirt idea! We tried this method for quite a while last week. Although we never came up with many great ideas, it seemed to keep us entertained for quite a while. I do have to say that the ideas were TOTALLY random, even if they weren't very funny.

I just got back from another trip to Manhattan last night. I didn't think that I would make it up there this week, but Brice called me the other day and asked if I wanted to go up there with him. Brice and I left Wichita Tuesday morning and pretty much hung out together all day. That worked out really well because Jermaine had to study most of the day, and she had a test Tuesday night and Wednesday morning. Tuesday After arriving in Manhattan, I went to eat at urlLink Chipotle with Brice, Brent, and Caleb (Brent's friend). Then we went to the mall for a bit so that Brice could do some Christmas shopping. We also spent like half an hour buying cigars (there were way too many to choose from). I ended up getting the Macanudo Maduro Hampton Court. It came in a cool case. Kyle went to buy a cigar later that night. I told him to ask the people that work there about two indecisive Mexicans and a white kid that were in there earlier. That way, he could see which cigars we got, and he could get a different one. He asked them, and they actually knew who he was talking about! But they couldn't remember which cigars we had picked out. After the mall, I went over to Jermaine's house while Brice went to visit one of his old professors. Jermaine had to study most of the time that I was there, but it gave me a chance to remove a virus from her computer... It's too bad that I broke her Internet in the process... At 8:00pm, I went over to Paul Scheele's house to smoke cigars and drink urlLink Guinness with Brice, Brent, Justin, and Kyle. I have never been a big fan of Guinness, but this stuff was really good. We had the Guinness Draught in bottles. Paul gave us glasses to pour it in because he just found out that beer tastes better if you let it breathe. It was really good stuff. We left Paul's house and went back to Putnam. Kyle had to study for a wicked hard final, but the rest of us decided to watch urlLink Fight Club (Brent had never seen it). I got back to Lindsey's around 1:30am. I tried to order stuff online, but Columbia House sucks! Wednesday Wednesday was nice because Jermaine was all done with finals, so I was able to see her quite a bit. I went with Lindsey to Wal-Mart to help her print some pictures for her project. After lunch I went with Jermaine to run a few errands. We had dinner at urlLink Quiznos (mmm... toasty). Jermaine volunteered to work for Amy for a little while so that Amy could go to a review session. While Jermaine was working, I went with Justin to Acacia, and we started watching The Two Towers extended edition DVD. I left after like an hour though. I can't wait to see The Return of the King ! Thursday I was able to spend quite a bit of time with Jermaine on Thursday too. We went to the Beach Art Museum and looked at a sweet exhibit! It was called urlLink Everything Must Go by Randy Regier. The exhibit "transforms a gallery space into a self-contained toy store." But the cool thing about the toys is that this guy made all of them! They are all supposed to be a joke though. I love how he made them look like they were really old and came out of the 50s and 60s. It was some very cool stuff. Jermaine had to go back to work at 9:00pm. I went to Putnam to say goodbye to some people, and I went down to Quik Cats to hang out with Jermaine for a little while. Lindsey came to pick me up around 10:00pm, and we left Manhattan around 11:00pm. I am pretty mad at myself because I left my camera at Lindsey's house! I really want to have that for Christmas! Despite leaving my camera there, I had a pretty good time in Manhattan this week.

I guess I should probably explain the urlLink previous posting that I made. Last year there was some confusion between Ben (my brother) and I. After reading urlLink Yugo's blog about his top 10 albums of all time, I thought it would be fun to make my own list. I thought I would list the albums that were most influential to me. These may not necessarily be my current favorite albums, but these are the albums that helped shape my musical preferences. Also, I don't really feel like putting them in order, so I am just going to list them. Squad Five-O - What I Believe I bought this CD at the Squad Five-O concert in 1997, my first punk show ever! Darian and I couldn't find the place, so we were really late. It was supposed to be $5 to get in, but no one was at the door to take our money. We decided to spend that money on the band's merchandise instead. The radio station said that they were a ska band, and I was really into ska at the time. It was a huge shock when I discovered they weren't a ska band. This is where I first began to fall in love with punk rawk. MxPx - Life In General This is probably still my favorite album ever. Every song on this album absolutely rocks, and MxPx has been my favorite band ever since I first heard this CD. I had never heard any band play this fast... I loved it! Various Artists - Song's From the Penalty Box (Vol. 1) I got this CD because I liked many of the punk bands on it, but that's not what made this CD so special to me. There were several bands on there that were a little too rough for me (Blindside, Living Sacrifice, Zao). At first, Darian and I listened to those bands and just laughed. But after a while, we began to really like those songs, and next thing I know, we were buying the CDs. Weezer - Blue Album How could anyone not like this album? (that's what I keep asking urlLink Zach ) Every song on it is really good, and Weezer had some great music videos to go along with it. All of my friends in high school loved these guys. Less Than Jake - Losing Streak I noticed that Yugo also had a Less Than Jake album on his list. Losing Streak is still my favorite Less Than Jake album. I think I picked it up at Best Buy for like $6 or something. It was one of the best music purchases I ever made. I love how Less Than Jake considers themselves a punk band with horns rather than a ska band. MxPx - Slowly Going The Way Of The Buffalo I wasn't a huge fan of this CD when it first came out (my senior year of high school I think). I guess I was still stuck on Life In General . But I gave the album another chance in college, and now it's on this list. In many ways, it's much better than Life In General . Ramones - Ramones Mania This was the first Ramones album that I ever bought. It's just a collection of their greatest hits (well, most of their greatest hits). When I got this CD, I didn't even realize that the Ramones had broken up just a couple years earlier. Can you believe that they were together for over 20 years?!?! That's really impressive considering they didn't have a lot of commercial success. They fixed everything that the Beatles screwed up. Face to Face - Self-Titled I joined one of those music clubs my freshman year of college. I was supposed to make some initial CD selections to get for free, and I had one left and didn't know what else I wanted. I had heard of Face to Face before, but I had never heard any of their music. I took a chance on it, and I loved it. It's too bad that they broke up this year. Huntingtons - High School Rock The Huntingtons are the ultimate Ramones rip-off band. This is by far their best album. Everything before this was recorded poorly, and I don't like much of their stuff after this album (except File Under Ramones of course). Arthur - Loneliness is Bliss Arthur is the side project of the guys in MxPx. Mike was writing a lot of slower, more EMOtional songs that he didn't feel really fit MxPx. So the guys from MxPx formed Arthur and put out this six-song EP. I love Arthur as much, if not more than MxPx. They were supposed to release a full CD a while ago, but it never came out.

Ok, sometimes I don't understand the urlLink Academy Awards at all! I was looking at urlLink this year's nominees , and I made it down to the Best Film Editing section. That's when I noticed that it's pretty much all of the same movies that were nominated for almost every category. The thing is that out of the movies that I have seen that were nominated for best editing, I don't remember any of them being that special when it comes to editing. I do have to admit that it would be quite a task to have to edit one of the Lord of the rings movies, trying to get it down to 3 hours. But for the most part, all of them were edited the way that almost every other movie is now edited. I know I bring up urlLink Hulk quite a bit, but why wasn't it nominated for best editing? I mean, the editing in that movie was simply amazing! I had never seen anything like it before in my life. Say what you want about the story. Sure it's just another in the long line of comic book movies being released now. But that movie was just beautiful. The only problem is that it didn't make as much money as urlLink Spider-Man at the box office. And it wasn't one of the biggest epics of all time like urlLink The Return of the King . So I guess those are good enough excuses for the Academy to just ignore it. I dunno... maybe I just don't understand what qualifies as good film editing.

Well, I started building my new web site today. I think that this one may end up being more of a trial run to help me figure out how to do some things in CSS. I am going to try this table-less CSS stuff. It seems to be pretty tricky so far. Just when I think I have figured it out and I know what I am doing, something weird happens. I feel like I am trying to program again. So far, it almost seems like every page is going to have to be typed out rather than put together in Dreamweaver. When I am working on a page in Dreamweaver, everything looks all messed up. I don't know if that is normal or not. If I am going to have to do every page by hand, it may take me a little bit longer to make all of my pages. But like I said, I am still trying to figure this whole thing out, so I could be wrong. I am just glad to have the hard part pretty much over with... designing a layout. I get so frustrated sometimes when I am trying to make layouts. I am not a great graphic designer, but that doesn't keep me from wanting everything to look perfect. I know what I want in a layout, but I just have trouble making it look good. I think I finally have a fairly simple layout that I can live with... well, for at least a week or two.

This is part of a message from Chris Pirillo at urlLink Lockergnome : For years, I've witnessed people putting off the inevitable upgrade - stating that they're waiting for digital cameras to "get as good as" their film predecessors. I know plenty of professional photographers who've already made the leap and would never consider turning back. Photoshop, to them, is a part of Maslow's Hierarchy. When Kodak made their urlLink earth-shattering announcement the other day, I was far from surprised. They're no longer going to produce traditional cameras, opting to concentrate on the future of the industry. I can't think of the last time I had a roll processed; the idea (to me) seems as archaic as having only three channels on the television. What's going on here? Progress. Change. It happens - and you either accept it and adapt, or you suffer from yesterdayism. I totally agree with Chris on this one. I know of a few people that are really stuck on film, and say that they will never like digital as much. I never understood that. It doesn't make any sense to me. Digital cameras are wicked cool. They are the future of photography. Get over it. UPDATE: I can understand why people would want to continue using film cameras, and there's nothing wrong with that. In fact, I want to get a new film camera some time. It's the people that are totally against ever going to digital that I don't understand. People that are like, "I've always shot on film, and that's the way real photographers should shoot." I watched a video in one of my classes that had a photographer saying that the reason that he doesn't use digital is because most photographers that shoot with digital cameras delete most of what they think are unimportant photos. He said that the photos they delete may be important some day, but they would have deleted them already. The whole time I was just wondering why he couldn't have a digital camera and just not delete his photos. I didn't understand his problem with digital cameras at all.

Here is a cool trick that I read about on urlLink Lockergnome : In response to the last Gnewbie Gnook of the year in which Gnomie Michael told us how to check the legitimacy of a URL by typing: javascript:alert("The real URL of this site is: " + location.protocol + "//" + location.hostname + "/"); into your address bar, Ron Goers writes: I have been plagued with spoofs [of] PayPal and eBay lately. Many messages are obvious, but some are real good fakes. A few go as far as stealing the graphics off the real Web site, and set up theirs to look just like it. I was pleased to find the tip from Michael in today's issue of Lockergnome Windows Fanatics. I went one step farther... I used the snippet of code to create a link on my IE toolbar. Now, any time I visit a site I'm unsure of, I simply click the link, and it reveals the real identity of the site. Cool! That's what I like so much about LG... great people sharing great tips!

urlLink Zach sent me this from urlLink IMDB : The cast of hit show Friends have been given a record breaking $2 million each to make a reunion special that takes place one year after the program's finale. Jennifer Aniston, Courteney Cox. Lisa Kudrow, Matt LeBlanc, Matthew Perry and David Schwimmer all agreed to make the single 90- minute special, which will be filmed right after shooting finishes on the last ever episode of the Manhattan-based comedy. A spokesperson for television network NBC says, "We knew it would be tough to get the Friends stars together again once they'd gone their separate ways. So we put an offer on the table to persuade them to film the reunion right away." In the special one-off viewers will see the New York sixsome come together for Thanksgiving dinner, which will be screened in conjunction with the holiday in America during November. The way I see it, NBC is getting a really good deal on this reunion show. Right now, each star of Friends is paid $1 million per epsiode. That's $1 million for 30 minutes. The reunion episode is 90 minutes long, which would normally cost $3 millon per person, but NBC is only paying $2 million per person. NBC is saving $1 million per person! What a great deal!

I just found this on urlLink Lockergnome : Windows XP SP2 will include a long-awaited concurrency feature that will let multiple users connect simultaneously to the same PC. The feature is mysteriously absent in the current SP2 beta release, and how Microsoft will implement the feature and how many concurrent interactive users it will support is unclear, but a Microsoft representative confirmed to me this week that the concurrent sessions feature, called multisessions internally, is happening. The next XP Media Center Edition (MCE) version, due this fall, will use the feature to enable as many as five Media Center sessions to remote Windows Media Center Extender devices.

Andy Rooney said on 60 minutes a few weeks back: (for those of you who don't know Andy Rooney, he is an 82-year-old American TV commentator) I like big cars, big boats, big motorcycles, big houses and big campfires. I believe the money I make belongs to me and my family, not some governmental stooge with a bad comb-over who wants to give it away to crack addicts for squirting out babies. Guns do not make you a killer. I think killing makes you a killer. You can kill someone with a baseball bat or a car, but no one is trying to ban you from driving to the ball game. I believe they are called the Boy Scouts for a reason, that is why there are no girls allowed. Girls belong in the Girl Scouts! ARE YOU LISTENING MARTHA BURKE? I think that if you feel homosexuality is wrong, it is not a phobia, it is an opinion. I don't think being a minority makes you a victim of anything except numbers. The only things I can think of that are truly discriminatory are The United Negro College Fund, Jet Magazine, Black Entertainment Television, and Miss Black America. Try to have things like the United Caucasian College Fund, Cloud Magazine, White Entertainment Television, or Miss White America; and see what happens. Jesse Jackson (and his illegitimate kids) will be knocking down your door. I have the right "NOT" to be tolerant of others because they are different, weird, or tick me off. When 70% of the people who get arrested are black, in cities where 70% of the population is black, that is not racial profiling, it is the Law of Probability. I know what sex is, and there are not varying degrees of it. If I received sex from one of my subordinates in my office, it wouldn't be a private matter or my personal business. I would be "FIRED" immediately! I believe that if you are selling me a milk shake, a pack of cigarettes, a newspaper or a hotel room, you must do it in English! As a matter of fact, if you want to be an American citizen, you should be required to speak English! My father and grandfather didn't die in vain so you can leave the countries you were born in to come over and disrespect ours. I think the police should have every right to shoot your sorry _ _ _ if you threaten them after they tell you to stop. If you can't understand the word "freeze" or "stop" in English, see the above paragraph. I feel much safer letting a machine with no political affiliation recount votes when needed and I know what the definition of lying is. I don't think just because you were not born in this country, you are qualified for any special loan programs, government sponsored bank loans or tax breaks, etc., so you can open a hotel, coffee shop, trinket store, or any other business. We did not go to the aid of certain foreign countries and risk our lives in wars to defend their freedoms, so that decades later they could come over here and tell us our constitution is a living document; and open to their interpretations. I don't hate the rich. I don't pity the poor. I know pro wrestling is fake, but so are movies and television. That doesn't stop you from watching them. I believe a self-righteous liberal or conservative with a cause is more dangerous than a Hell's Angel with an attitude. I think Bill Gates has every right to keep every penny he made and continue to make more. If it ticks you off, go and invent the next operating system that's better, and put your name on the building. Ask your buddy, Al Gore, who invented the Internet, to help you. It doesn't take a whole village to raise a child right, but it does take a parent to stand up to the kid; and smack the little b---- ds when necessary, and say "NO!" I think tattoos and piercing are fine if you want them, but please don't pretend they are a political statement. And, please, stay home until that new lip ring heals. I don't want to look at your ugly infected mouth as you serve me French fries! I am sick of "Political Correctness." I know a lot of black people, and not a single one of them was born in Africa; so how can they be "African-Americans"? Besides, Africa is a continent. I don't go around saying I am a European-American because my great, great, great, great, great, great grandfather was from Europe. I am proud to be from America and nowhere else. And if you don't like my point of view, tough. DON'T PASS IT ON!! I did like it so I am passing it on. Do what you like.

I received a letter today that makes me laugh every time I think about it. Quite a while ago I went to a web site to register for my part of a settlement involving the music industry. By registering, I could be entitled to a payment. I had almost completely forgotten about it until I received this letter. Dear Kansas Music Purchaser: As Attorney General for the state of Kansas, I am pleased to enclose payment for your claim in the settlement of the Compact Disc Minimum Advertised Price Antitrust Litigation. The lawsuit was brought by the counsel for Private Class Plaintiffs on behalf of purchasers of music CDs. In accordance with the terms of the court-approved settlement, payment is being made to music purchasers who filed a valid and timely claim. Whether you filed your claim online at the settlement web site, urlLink www.MusicCDSettlement.com , or by mail, the attached payment represents full payment of your portion of the Settlement. Please note that the attached payment instrument must be cashed by May 20, 2004. It is a pleasure to bring this matter to a satisfactory conclusion and to return value to consumers who purchased CDs while the challenged pricing policies were in effect. Phill Kline Attorney General of Kansas Enclosed in the letter was a check for $13.86. I thought that if they ever sent me any money for this, it would only be like $2 or something. I was pretty surprised to see a check for over $13!

Blogger just posted another "Creative Tutorial." This one is about how to date and blog. Here is a bit of the article: "If you are dating a non-blogger, be gentle. Be patient. Explain the intricacies of the blogosphere to them. And if their eyes start rolling back in their heads, give them some espresso and forge ahead. Talk about how you blog and why you blog. And then come up with some guidelines for what is and isn't acceptable to share on your blog. He or she may not want you to use their real name. They may not want you to post pictures of them at that nude beach you visited last summer. These are reasonable requests, and it's important that you listen respectfully. Otherwise, you many end up alone and blogging on a Saturday night. Not that there's anything wrong with that." Hey, today is my mom's birthday, so I just wanted to wish her a happy birthday. I don't think anyone really knows how old she is because she has been lying about her age for as long as I can remember. I think she is thirty-something... ;-) Anyway, Happy Birthday Mom! There seemed to be a lot of people celebrating their birthdays at Golden Corral tonight. So to all those birthday people there, Happy Birthday!

urlLink Mozilla just changed the name of their "next-generation browser" from Firebird to Firefox. They also released version 0.8 today. They have made a lot of improvements from version 0.7, including the addition of an installer. The biggest problem I was having with Firebird was with the extensions. Some extensions did not seem to work well with others, and there was no way to remove the extensions once they were installed. I suppose that was mostly not Firebird's fault though. Other than the extensions, I really didn't have any problems. Because of the new release today, all of the Firefox extension web sites have gone down today due to heavy traffic. Firefox does a few things better than Opera, but I think that I will still stick with Opera for now. I just love it too much. But those of you who still use Internet Explorer should give Firefox a try. By the way, I just love the new Firefox logo. Here is where you can get some Firefox buttons to add to your web site: urlLink http://www.mozilla.org/products/firefox/buttons.html

DVDFILE.COM did an interview with one of my favorite directors, Robert Rodriguez. Here is a bit of the interview: As many converts to the digital cause as there are, there are also these people, say Roger Ebert, for example, who are very, very vociferous and angry almost. And there are filmmakers too who will say I will never abandon film. Do you think they misunderstand the techology? urlLink Absolutely. I mean film is a technology, too. People seem to think film is more organic, and it's like that doesn't grow on trees. You forget, it's such an old technology that that too is a technology, and we tend to forget that. It was just the best technology we could come up with at the time. And it's really just outdated at this point. But people who have a real love for nostalgia just don't want to hear that sort of thing. But I did get some great reviews from Roger Ebert on "Once Upon a Time in Mexico." He wrote actually the movie looks really great. So I was like, Yes, I finally broke him! That was cool. When George Lucas showed me some early footage from "Star Wars," I was like, Hey, I didn't know it was that far along. I hadn't heard a thing about it. I was actually angry that people had been hiding all that great information. So I went out and shot a test, and I went, Oh my God, people obviously don't even know what they're talking about it. That's been the case mostly. I saw that 10 years ago with editing. They didn't want anything to do with an Avid or a computer. So this was not real. You weren't touching the film. But the technology isn't the art form. Touching the film on a flat bed isn't editing. Editing is manipulating images. Whether you use a computer or not it's the same art form. So that's what I think Ebert needs to shift to, is to what is the art form truly? Story telling by moving images, but that's not tied to celluloid. Click the link below to read the rest of the interview. urlLink DVDFILE.COM: In the Director's Chair - Robert Rodriguez

I just came across a good article about how to make video look more like film. I don't understand everything in the article yet, but it is still very interesting. You will have to sign up for an account on this web site before you can view the article. urlLink DV.com: Features - How to Make Video Look like Film ... Here are some of the things in the article that I found interesting: "To get the best results, start long before you use any plug-in or proprietary process. The key building block is to shoot video with film production values: fine lighting, careful exposure, good composition, lens filters, and controlled camera motion. You must take as much care shooting the original video as does a film crew on a $50 million feature." "Deinterlacing is at the core of all post processes used to make video look like film... Some software deinterlaces by simply duplicating one of the fields, effectively halving the vertical resolution. Sony consumer camcorders also do this when they are operated at a shutter speed of 1/30 second. However, the Canon XL1, XL1S, and GL2 can run in a true 30p 'frame mode,' which has made the cameras attractive to filmmakers." "The effect of a subtle gamma curve change has a huge impact in perception. Highlights become more pastel, shadows become denser, and midrange colors appear more saturated." ... UPDATE: I was eager to try out some of the simple techniques that this article talked about, so I decided to mess with one of my old projects a little bit. I opened up my Secret of Women video and tried to adjust the colors. The article includes this graphic which shows the gamma curve differences between video and film: "(right) A typical film's gamma curve has a mild S shape, (left) while video cameras are usually engineered to have a flat gamma response. A gamma curve shows the distribution of gray values, or midrange tones." I opened up my video in urlLink Vegas and changed the color curves to look like the curve on the right. Here are the results: To me, this simple change makes the image so much better. When I was working on The Secret of Women , I wanted to try to fix the color after I finished editing. I ended up running out of time and never messed with the color at all. Now I wish that I had tried something like this a long time ago. I don't know if this makes the video look more like film, but it sure does look a lot better!

urlLink ITnews Australia Corel Announces WordPerfect Office 12 Corel, which is under new management, announced last week that it will issue a new WordPerfect Office release in April that will see the suite return to its former position of glory. Corel says that WordPerfect Office 12 will take on Microsoft Office 2003 head to head, offering lower prices and competitive features. And the company will no longer be content with simply selling upgrades to existing customers -- a losing strategy if there ever was one. To that end, WordPerfect Office 12 will offer document compatibility and even application compatibility with Microsoft Word; in other words, users who make the switch can configure WordPerfect to look and work exactly like Word does. "We're after the consumer and small- and mid-sized business market," Corel WordPerfect Product Manager Wendy Lowe said. "We've found that a lot of [people] are looking to an Office alternative and getting savvy that there are cheaper alternatives. That's where [WordPerfect Office] 12 plays nicely; it has a set of features comparable to the standard edition of Microsoft Office, but it's cheaper." I've always liked Corel WordPerfect better than Microsoft Word. It just seemed to work better for me. I've been using WordPerfect Office 2000 for about five years now. I should probably think about upgrading.

From the Thursday edition of the urlLink Lockergnome Windows Fanatics Newsletter . urlLink http://shortscripts.com/ {Share and find short scripts} Film makers and Spielberg wanna-bes, this is the place for you. Short Scripts is a central "meeting" spot, so to speak, for finding and letting others know about your short scripts. The site doesn't store the scripts, but rather stores the summary and e-mail contact information so you know where to go. Its sole purpose is short scripts and it costs nothing to use the site. Copyright concerns? The FAQ addresses that. I wonder if any interesting stories have resulted from the contacts made on the site. [ urlLink Meryl ]

This is from Tuesday's urlLink Lockergnome Windows Fanatics Newsletter . Gnomie Ron Enderland writes: I had a DSL account with Southwestern Bell. When they cut some sort of deal with Yahoo! to take over DSL, I instantly started getting spam on my swbell.net e-mail address. This is an address that I never, ever used, or posted anywhere! The only reason I even checked it for mail was because SWBell would occasionally send me DSL news and account updates. I complained to Yahoo! about it, and got some clueless automatic reply about what to do if a user abuses one of their free e-mail accounts (confirming that they don't read customers' e-mails). My tiny revenge: leave all messages on the server. Eventually, the spam they got me by selling my e-mail adrress will take up noticable server space (I hope).

urlLink You are Joshua Abraham Norton, first and only Emperor of the United States of America! Born in England sometime in the second decade of the nineteenth century, you carved a notable business career, in South Africa and later San Francisco, until an entry into the rice market wiped out your fortune in 1854. After this, you became quite different. The first sign of this came on September 17, 1859, when you expressed your dissatisfaction with the political situation in America by declaring yourself Norton I, Emperor of the USA. You remained as such, unchallenged, for twenty-one years. Within a month you had decreed the dissolution of Congress. When this was largely ignored, you summoned all interested parties to discuss the matter in a music hall, and then summoned the army to quell the rebellious leaders in Washington. This did not work. Magnanimously, you decreed (eventually) that Congress could remain for the time being. However, you disbanded both major political parties in 1869, as well as instituting a fine of $25 for using the abominable nickname "Frisco" for your home city. Your days consisted of parading around your domain - the San Francisco streets - in a uniform of royal blue with gold epaulettes. This was set off by a beaver hat and umbrella. You dispensed philosophy and inspected the state of sidewalks and the police with equal aplomb. You were a great ally of the maligned Chinese of the city, and once dispersed a riot by standing between the Chinese and their would-be assailants and reciting the Lord's Prayer quietly, head bowed. Once arrested, you were swiftly pardoned by the Police Chief with all apologies, after which all policemen were ordered to salute you on the street. Your renown grew. Proprietors of respectable establishments fixed brass plaques to their walls proclaiming your patronage; musical and theatrical performances invariably reserved seats for you and your two dogs. (As an aside, you were a good friend of Mark Twain, who wrote an epitaph for one of your faithful hounds, Bummer.) The Census of 1870 listed your occupation as "Emperor". The Board of Supervisors of San Francisco, upon noticing the slightly delapidated state of your attire, replaced it at their own expense. You responded graciously by granting a patent of nobility to each member. Your death, collapsing on the street on January 8, 1880, made front page news under the headline "Le Roi est Mort". Aside from what you had on your person, your possessions amounted to a single sovereign, a collection of walking sticks, an old sabre, your correspondence with Queen Victoria and 1,098,235 shares of stock in a worthless gold mine. Your funeral cortege was of 30,000 people and over two miles long. The burial was marked by a total eclipse of the sun. urlLink Which Historical Lunatic Are You ? urlLink From the fecund loins of Rum and Monkey.

I found this link on urlLink Darian's blog . This is a production company run by some guys in Belgium. urlLink another state of mind Their photos and videos look great, but what makes these guys even more impressive is that they made urlLink their own Mini35 kit . This is a kit that allows them to shoot MiniDV video through an old SLR film camera to give their digital video a film look. They used this kit along with a Canon GL-2 to make their short film urlLink Marla . I have done a little bit of research in the past (mostly on urlLink Google ) to try to find out if there was a way to make digital video look more like film. I had no idea that something like this was possible, which is weird because, like Darian pointed out, there are Mini35 kits available to buy. I guess I really suck at looking stuff up on Google. Ok, now I just have a ton of questions about how this Mini35 thing works. Why is the MiniDV camera pointing down onto the top of the film camera and not into the back of the film camera? Did they have to take that film camera apart to get this to work? Did they have to adjust the video much in post-production to get it to look more like film? These are just a few of the questions that I have about this kit. I hope they come out with some kind of tutorial for how to build a Mini35 kit because I want to make one now. I already told my brother that I am going to have to "borrow" his 35mm camera once I get a MiniDV camera... Marla is pretty cool by the way. From what I gathered, it's kind of a side story from the movie urlLink Fight Club . Anyway, I suggest that you go to their web site and watch it for yourself.
Who returns a can of tuna at 3 in the morning? Come on people!

Ok, those of you who know when I started reading the first Lord of the Rings book will find this really funny... Last night I finished reading The Fellowship of the Ring ! That's right, it only took me a little over two years to finish it. I have been reading it every day at work during my "lunch" break. I have been really bad about finishing books. I started reading several books in college that I just never finished. I am trying to break this habit now. I am also trying to spend at least a little bit of time reading every day. Having an hour-long break at work really helps. One thing that I liked about reading The Fellowship of the Ring after I have seen the movie is that I know what's going on in the story no matter how long it has been since I last picked up the book. There are a few changes that were made in the movie, but for the most part everything is the same. The book just adds a lot of little details that the movie had to leave out. Now that I am done with the first book, I am ready to start reading The Two Towers . It looks a bit smaller than the first book, so I am hoping to have it done in about a year and a half...

Well, I have been working at Wal-Mart for a whole week now. So far I really like it. The job is pretty easy, it's just really tiring. When I get home at 7:00am, I am ready to go to bed! So my schedule goes something like this now... I work from 10:00pm to 7:00am. I get home by 7:20am each day (I have to have my dad's car back so that he can go to work and take my brother to school). I sleep from 7:30 or 8:00am until about 3:00 or 4:00pm. I then have a few hours of free time before I have to go back to work. One cool thing about third-shift stocking is that we don't have to be at work for our entire shift. We can leave whenever our work is finished. We have already finished early a couple times since I have been there. The only bad thing is that stockers also have to work until everything is finished. So if 7:00am comes around and things aren't done, someone has to stay and finish it. I don't really have a way to stay though because, like I said, I have to get my dad's car back to him. So far this hasn't been much of a problem though. I will be working Tuesday through Saturday, and I will have Sunday and Monday nights off. This makes things kind of weird because I pretty much miss the entire weekend. I have also found that this will make it interesting to try to make it to church on Sunday mornings at 11:00am. I think I will just take a short nap, get up for church, then sleep some more after church. The store that I work at is in the process of expanding from a normal Wal-Mart into a Super Wal-Mart. The grocery side will be opening later this month. They told me that this store used to be the busiest store in the region until Wichita opened a Super Wal-Mart on the west side. They are hoping that it will once again be the busiest once this new addition is completed... fun fun... With the new expansion, the store had to hire about 35 temporary employees. That is in addition to the regular full-time spots they had to fill. I was lucky enough to get a full-time spot, so I will be able to keep my job when the grocery side opens. The store hangs every new employee's photo on a wall in the break room. Last time I counted, there were 64 photos on that wall. That's pretty crazy. I know that my strange schedule and new job isn't too exciting to read about, but I thought that I should just post something about it.
Dang, I wish I could go to this! Maybe I could meet Robert Rodriguez there... urlLink SXSW

Wow, I think this guy upset quite a few bloggers with this article. The writer claims that blogging is over-rated and pointless. He also makes a few dumb statements such as this one: "I wish there were some way of licensing who can blog and who can't; then we could say there were some with quality." If you had to get a license to blog, then all blogs would be exactly like the T.V. stations, radio stations, and popular books that we already have because it would most likely be the same kinds of people creating all of the blogs. Oh yeah, we would all also have to be communists for that to happen. And by the way, we already have some blogs "with quality." We don't need licensing for that! urlLink Geek.com Geek News - Blogging--survey says, "Not so hot" You know, I was just thinking that if this was 10 or 15 years ago, this guy would probably be saying that the Internet is over-rated because any idiot with a computer can make a web site.

For those of you who don't know, I got a finally job last week. I will be an overnight stocker at the local urlLink Wal-Mart . I know it doesn't really sound like any kind of dream job, but in a weird way, it sort of is for me. I have been wanting to try being an overnight stocker at a retail store for a while. I was almost one when I worked at Builders Square, but they ended up changing the shift to start at like 5am! So I just took another shift. I think the overnight stocker position sounds fun though. There won't be as many customers around, and it just sounds like it would be cool to get paid to stay up all night. I have never been happy about having to start working at 7 or 8 in the morning. Plus, the overnight positions get paid $1 an hour more than the other positions. I start my new job tonight at 10pm, and I will be working until 7am. I just hope that I can stay awake. Last night I stayed up until 4:30 or 5:00am so that I could sleep in later today and be as rested as possible for work tonight. I'm still not sure how well I will adjust to this new schedule. The way I see it, I have almost the same schedule as my dad and brother. But instead of working or going to school from 7am until about 4pm, I am sleeping. And instead of sleeping from 10pm to 7am, I am working. I just hope that my body agrees with this theory. I am pretty nervous about starting my job tonight. One reason is that it's new, and I always get nervous when I start something new. I am also nervous because I still don't know exactly what I will be doing. I mean, I get the basic idea, but I still don't know all of the details about my job yet. I am also worried that the sudden change in schedule will come as quite a shock to me. I'm used to doing pretty much nothing all day. Now I will only have a few hours of free time every day. I'm sure that it won't take too long to get used to though. It never has before. But then again, this is the longest amount of time that I have ever spent doing nothing before. I am just happy to have some kind of job. I really really needed to start working and make some money. I know that it was God that gave me this job, and I am extremely thankful. I am going to try really hard to make the most out of this opportunity. Who knows, this may end up being the most fun job I've ever had!

A couple moths ago I started looking at a lot of "photo blogs" on the Internet. Looking at these photo blog sites really made me want to start taking more pictures so that I could have my own little photo blog. One site in particular that really inspired me was a site called urlLink apparently nothing at all . The reason that I like this site so much is that most of the photos on it were taken with a urlLink Canon Powershot S30 , the very same camera that I own. This proved to me that my camera really has the ability to produce great photos, I just need to become a better photographer. Now that my camera has been returned to me after I left it in Manhattan for a couple months, I am going to try to post my photos on my blog at least a couple times a week. I'm sure that most of them are going to really suck, but at least it gives me a reason to practice taking more photos. So here is my first photo. This was taken today... or I guess it was technically yesterday (Sunday)... I really hate camera flashes. They always make my photos look way to bright, and thus crappy. Sometimes I turn on the flash just to make something really weird happen. This is one of those times. I was outside taking pictures of some cool looking clouds with my brother urlLink Ben . I was trying to take a picture of him with the clouds in the background, but the background was too bright and he was too dark. I just turned the flash on to see what would happen. I have another photo of him that is very similar.

In case you haven't noticed, I've made another small addition to my sidebar. I've started another blog on urlLink Blogger for all of the interesting sites that I find on the Internet. I did this so that I wouldn't have so many posts in my personal blog that are nothing but links. I haven't set up the archive pages yet, but once I do, I will be able to have a short description for each link. You can find this new blog under the title Bookmarks in my sidebar.

I haven't been posting much lately. It seems like I have had a lot of stuff to talk about, but I have just been too lazy to type it. I have also been trying to get my web site re-structured. I never really finished this design either. My site has a lot of problems, so I decided to pretty much start over. I hope that I can get it finished during my next days off. Last Wednesday, the urlLink Wal-Mart store where I work had it's grand opening as a Wal-Mart Supercenter. Rather than close the store down and re-build a new building, Wal-Mart decided that they would just expand the current store while keeping most of it open. The only new thing that the grand opening added to the store was most of the grocery section. I took my camera to work with me last week to take some pictures. There are a lot of funny signs and things at work. I will probably put them up once I get my new photo blog started. My brother was also able to borrow a urlLink Lomo LC-A camera from his teacher, so we went out and took a bunch of pictures with it. I got those back today, so I will post them soon as well. I was really excited to try out that camera. My black and white photos seemed to come out better than my color photos. Maybe that is because I bought the cheapest color film that I could find at Wal-Mart. The urlLink NHL playoffs have started, and so far I have only been late to work twice. It wouldn't be such a problem if the games didn't keep going into overtime. The first round of the playoffs is great because there are usually four games every night. urlLink ESPN used to play all four games every night. They would have two on ESPN and two on ESPN2. They haven't really done that this year. They have only been showing two or three. I don't know why.

I woke up this afternoon expecting to watch the hockey game on urlLink ABC . I checked urlLink ESPN's web site this morning before I went to bed, and found that there would be a game starting on ABC at 2pm Central Time. I decided that I could wake up in time to watch the last period of the game. When I woke up this afternoon, the game was not on ABC. Instead, the local ABC affiliate, urlLink KAKE , decided to replace the hockey game with a literacy telethon. This did not make me happy at all. Although the telethon is a good thing to do for the community, I think KAKE made a very poor choice when they decided to not play the hockey game. It would have been different if they would have normally been playing re-runs or a movie or something today. The hockey game is meant to be a live event. You can only watch it live once. Even if they re-played the game later (as if ABC would even do that), most people would not watch or enjoy it because they already know what happens. KAKE probably upset most of the hockey fans in Wichita by not playing the hockey game. Also, I don't even know how KAKE was able to replace something like a hockey game. I would think that ABC wouldn't like that very much. There are a lot of advertisers that have paid ABC to play their ads on national TV. How does that work out if all of the affiliates are not playing the game or the ads that go with the game? Instead of having a telefund, why didn't KAKE just give the literacy fund all of the money they would have made off of local ads they play during the game? Maybe the ads from one hockey game wouldn't have raised as much money, but they had been playing that telefund all day. I'm sure that all of the ads for the day would have come close to raising that much money. I know that it sounds like I am making a big deal out of this whole situation, but this is just one of those things that really annoys me. I don't think KAKE would have done this for any other major sport, like the basketball playoffs. They probably just thought that no one would care. I think it just makes me feel better to complain about it on my blog. As I was telling my dad and brother today, it's probably a good thing that KAKE was having a literacy telefund, because now they can learn to read the schedule to find out when they are supposed to be playing the hockey games on their station.
